column1: Time is a very odd sort of thing
column2: dear readers. We neither know whence it comes nor whither it goes;—nay we know nothing about it in fact except that there is one little moment of it called the present
column3: which we have as it were in our hands to make use of—but beyond this we can give no account of
column4: even that little moment. It is ours to use
column5: but not to understand. There is one thing in the world
column10: the Wind. Did it never strike you how strange it was that the strongest thing in the world should be invisible? The nice breezes we feel in summer and the roughest blasts we feel in winter in England are not so extremely strong you will say: but I am speaking
column12: of the winds called hurricanes that arise in the West Indian Islands
column13: and in other places in the world. These dreadful hurricanes have at times done as much mischief as earthquakes and lightning.
